title: Citi, SPbU Graduate School of Management and the Higher School of Economics Announce Global Entrepreneurship Monitor 2011 Results for Russia
summary: Moscow/St. Petersburg - A presentation of Global Entrepreneurship Monitor Russia 2011, the sixth GEM report for the country, was held in Moscow. The results show that only 1 in 22 Russians (4.6 percent of the population) of working age are early-stage entrepreneurs. For comparison, entrepreneurship plays a much larger role in other BRICS countries. For example, every fourth respondent in China is an early-stage entrepreneur, every seventh in Brazil and every 10th in South Africa.
tag-1: Citi, SPbU Graduate School of Management and the Higher School of Economics Announce Global Entrepreneurship Monitor 2011 Results for Russia
tag-3: Moscow/St. Petersburg – A presentation of Global Entrepreneurship Monitor Russia 2011, the sixth GEM report for the country, was held in Moscow. The results show that only 1 in 22 Russians (4.6 percent of the population) of working age are early-stage entrepreneurs. For comparison, entrepreneurship plays a much larger role in other BRICS countries. For example, every fourth respondent in China is an early-stage entrepreneur, every seventh in Brazil and every 10th in South Africa.
tag-4: In Russia, only 2.8 percent of the working-age population own established businesses (more than 3.5 years in business). This indicates that only a few nascent businesspeople prove able to overcoming barriers the barriers related to the early development stage of a business. For every 160 early-stage entrepreneurs, there are only 100 established entrepreneurs. In economically developed countries the number of established business owners exceeds the number of early-stage entrepreneurs.
tag-5: The main reason for the discontinuation of a business is its unprofitability, which is connected with entrepreneurs' lack of ability to at the start objectively assess the prospects of their business. Most of those who discontinue their business (58 percent) have no plans to further engage in entrepreneurial activities.
tag-6: For most entrepreneurs in Russia, opening their business was an opportunity-driven choice; however, most often their basic motivation is to maintain previous levels of income, as opposed to improving income or attaining independence.
tag-7: According to the conclusions drawn in the Russian portion of the study, only an insignificant number of the respondents plan to open their own business in the near future. Only 1 in 20 Russian citizens of working age wants to create a new company. This is the lowest indicator for all countries included in the study. Of countries with a comparable level of development, on average, 1 in 4 declares intentions of becoming an entrepreneur.
tag-8: Among respondents with entrepreneurial intentions in Russia, approximately 40 percent are already entrepreneurs planning to open another business. The share of potential new entrepreneurs in Russia amounted to a mere 3.6 percent of the population in 2011.
tag-9: "Non-entrepreneurs have a negative outlook on business opportunities: in 2011 only 19 percent of them consider the conditions to be conducive to starting a business. Eighty-two percent of Russian citizens who are not engaged in entrepreneurial activities believe that they lack the required knowledge and skills for running a business. Meanwhile, only 20 percent of entrepreneurs doubt their own competency. Half of the population fears failure in such entrepreneurial endeavors. Among those who have already launched their business, only one-fourth fear this," says Professor Alexander Chepurenko, Academic Supervisor at the Laboratory of Entrepreneurship Research at the National Research University – Higher School of Economics.
tag-10: "The decision to support this research in particular and double its scale was guided by the fact the GEM methodology is unique throughout the world, which allows to evaluate entrepreneurial activities and compare Russia to the rest of the world on the basis of a unified evaluation matrix," notes Viktor Rozhkov, Russian Commercial Banking Head at Citibank. "This research presents a unique analysis and empirical data to anyone interested in the topics of developing entrepreneurship and its environment. It is very important for Citi as we believe it is necessary to facilitate the development entrepreneurship as one of the main factors for improving the social and economic well being of society. It is apparent in the research that the main reason for the closing of early-stage businesses is unprofitability (45 percent), which in my opinion point to a lack of financial literacy, experience in business planning and basic business skills. This is the reason why the main component of our social programs is entrepreneurial training."
tag-11: "The reason for the low level of entrepreneurial activity can be found in the general public's attitude toward entrepreneurs and entrepreneurship. And although 20 percent of Russians say that opening a business is a good career choice, only a few truly consider this opportunity. Only 8 percent of Russians believe that they are capable of running a business and see good prospects for creating a company," notes Olga Verkhovskaya, Associate Professor for the Department of Strategic & International Management, GSOM SPbU.
tag-12: The Russia 2011 report was published as a part of the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM) project, which at present is the largest assessment of entrepreneurial activity worldwide. In Russia the project is implemented by the Graduate School of Management at St. Petersburg University and the Laboratory of Entrepreneurship Research at the National Research University – Higher School of Economics (Moscow) with financial support provided by the Citi Foundation.
tag-13: The Graduate School of Management at St. Petersburg University  The Graduate School of Management at St. Petersburg University was created within the framework of the priority national project Education based on the Management Department at SPbU (created in alliance with the Haas School of Business, University of California at Berkeley, in 1993). The schools key programs – Executive MBA, Master's and a Bachelor's – have been received international accreditation (AMBA, CEMS, EPAS). GSOM SPbU is the only Russian business school that has been accepted into major business school association PIM, and it is a member of numerous prestigious professional associations, including AASCB, EFMD, GRLI, RABO and the Russian Managers Association. As an authoritative academic research center on management, the school regularly hosts international conferences and seminars. GSOM SPbU is an important communication platform for leaders of the international academic and business community as well as for the dialogue of business, academics and government representatives. For more information see the school's website: www.gsom.spbu.ru.
tag-14: The National Research University – Higher School of Economics (Moscow) The National Research University – Higher School of Economics (Moscow) was founded on November 27, 1992, by a directive of the Russian government. In October 2009 the Higher School of Economics received the status of a National Research University. On December 23, 2010, the university received the status of an autonomous educational institution (Decree of the Government of the Russian Federation No.1109 'On the creation of a federal state autonomous educational institution of higher professional education "National Research University – Higher School of Economics"'). Previously the school was officially known as State University – Higher School of Economics. The school is one of the leading institutions of higher education in Russia and a major research center.
